title: Council agrees budget for 2019 20
story: It says thebudget is set to deliver pound. million savings over the next three years with a "Change Fund" of pound. million set aside to help "resource and deliver the change programme".Investment of an additional and recurring pound. million for roads maintenance was also approved, with plans for how this will be spentto be brought to a future meeting of the councils development and infrastructure committee.Members also agreed to raise Council Tax by three per cent.Budget leader, Councillor Alister Mackinnon, said: ldquoOur workforce is vitally important to communities. Not just in the services they provide, but, as one of the biggest employers in Highland, council jobs are fundamental to the sustainability of many communities. So a budget for jobs is really good news for people.ldquoA key element of the feedback we received is that we have many cumbersome, complicated and bureaucratic processes. We need to do things dferently, streamlining processes, be more outward looking and adopt best practice.ldquoAn overwhelming message is that we need to be more efficient. Basically, we need to get a grip on our expenditure. As a result we have been examining every budget line and turning over every stone, to make sure that we are getting the best results from the resources being used and challenging where performance can be improved.ldquoIf you always do the same things in the same way, you will get the same results. It is time to change how we do things and so this is a budget for change."The change fund is an exciting element of our budget strategy and will underpin our programme of change over the coming year.Council leader Margaret Davidson said: ldquoThis is a decent, thoughtful and ambitious budget which will help move us into the future, protecting jobs and services."It aims to set the council on a journey of much needed change. We are all ambitious for improvement and what has struck me is the huge buy-in from all staff in challenging circumstances.ldquoThis budget will enable us to be sustainable and I am really confident that we have the necessary knowledge and expertise in our top team to take forward the change programme that is required.Chief executive Donna Manson added: ldquoThis budget process has been about us being connected. Connected to our communities, to our staff, to our partners, to each other ndash building relationships and enabling better conversations and improved understanding.ldquoI really appreciate the input from staff across the organisation during the whole engagement process, and for some really honest feedback. I am equally delighted with the really positive engagement across the political groups.ldquoWe need to manage all our resources, to redesign, to become more resilient, to be more efficient, to invest in our workforce and to plan for the future. We need to embed effective performance management and effective scrutiny.ldquoThe Corporate Plan will be coming to council in March and this will focus on scrutiny and driving performance. It will underpin the work of the council moving forward, ensuring that we use all our resources to the best effect ndash and the engagement with communities and staff will be a continuing process throughout the year. I look forward to getting back out to see staff from next week onwards.Wednesday  Feb  : AM

title: Council budget to mark the start of reform
story: Highland Council has agreed sweeping changes to this yearrsquos annual budget of around pound million with the aim of not just balancing the books ndash with measures addressing a funding gap of almost pound million ndash but to instigate major reforms in how it provides services.Last Thursday, councillors debated, amended and approved its budget with policies including a three per cent rise in council tax and rising costs of funerals, cremations, commercial refuse collections and bulky uplts, while fees for emptying brown bins will go up by pound per year.Leisure and culture provider High Le Highlandcame out better than thought after the SNP negotiated a rise in membership cost of pound or less which took pound, off the original pound, proposed cut.But in a major sht from previous years the financial measures were targeted to reform services ndash particularly education ndash where millions of pounds of savings are being sought by improving performance.In another break with tradition, many of the proposals are dependant on further consultations with staff and the public.Cuts include funding for additional support needs ndash when a child needs more or dferent support to get the most from school ndash in what is a major shake-up of the service which some fear could be too much for the public to stomach.Chief executive Donna Manson said: ldquoI call it a budget for change. Education transformation ndash it is all about getting better outcomes.ldquoWe will work through that in the next three years. I am committed to doing that, but the key to it will be regular monitoring.Wednesday  Feb  : AM

story: SUPPORTERS of a leline service for children and young adults with special needs are to take part in a sponsored cycle ride to raise desperately-needed funds.The Special Needs Action Projectis facing an uncertain future after Highland Council turned down the charityrsquos annual grant of pound, ndash  per cent of the total running costs of pound,.After hearing the charity might have to close, two members of Snaprsquos youth club decided to do something to help.Dean Stewart and Bradley Morrall, both aged , suggested a fundraiser and as a result, a sponsored cycle ride will be held on Saturday March  at the Highland Cycle Ability Centre at Cantraybridge.They and others aim to cycle  km by completing laps of the track.Deanrsquos mother Carol Macdonald said her son had attended Snap for many years.ldquoIt has enabled and encouraged him and many others to enjoy le, have fun, learn, grow and flourish with many dferent challenges, she said.ldquoSnap is a much-needed leline for children and young adults, families, siblings and carers.ldquoSnap is like a great big hug. title: Cyclists gather pollution data in Inverness
story: CLEAN air campaigners have strapped pollution sensors onto their bikes to expose the cityrsquos toxic air hotspots.The Highland Cycle Campaign is working with a student-led research project from Cambridge University to monitor air quality near roadways because of fears official figures are not capturing ldquodangerous levels of pollution.So far six members have used the pound monitors in ious areas including the A trunk road.And there are plans to extend its reach to the rest of the Highlands.Secretary Anne Thomas, who acts as local co-ordinator for Friends of the Earth Scotland, said the devices are showing where the most polluted areas are.She said: ldquoThe first maps show pollution levels on Academy Street and at the Longman roundabout as particularly high.And she claimed that the levels did seem, in some cases, to be breaching standards ldquowhich should have been met in .She added: ldquoIn reality there is no safe level of pollution which is responsible for thousands of premature deaths a year across Scotland.Mrs Thomas hopes the findings inspire more people to cycle as studies show car drivers spend longer in toxic air than walkers or cyclists on main roads.Wednesday  Feb  : AM

title: Date set for Eastgate Hostel demolition
story: Provost Carmichael said: ldquoThis is a key city centre location which has for too long been blighted by scaffolding. The reinstatement of the High Street is a signicant improvement and I welcome the commitment madeby the owners to invest in this key site.The demolition news, which emerged this morning,is also supported by central ward councillors Janet Campbell, Bet McAllister and Richard Laird.In a joint statement they said: ldquoThis is welcome news especially for the businesses in the High Street. We are also pleased to see that the owners plan to liaise closely with businesses on the demolition work so as to minimise disruption.For more details and further reaction to the news see the next edition of the paper.Wednesday  Feb  : AM

title: False alarm at Inverness Leisure
story: A FIRE alert at Inverness Leisure this afternoon was a  alarm.One unit from Inverness Fire Station attended at the leisure centre beside Bught Park shortly after pm but a fire service spokesman said it turned out that an alarm had been triggered by moisture.The centre, run by Highle Highland, did not have to be evacuated but customers were prevented from entering for a short time.Wednesday  Feb  : AM

title: Focus on art of of sport in new Inverness exhibition
story: ART and shinty have become the perfect match for an exhibition that celebrates the culture and heritage of one of Scotlandrsquos oldest sports.The work ndash known as the Throw Up . project ndash is on show at Inverness Museum and Art Gallery until March .Organised by Invernessrsquos Highland Print Studio and funded by Highland Culture Strategic Boardrsquos Highland Culture: Take Pride, Take Part programme, four artists were commissioned to work with designated shinty clubs during  and into the  season.The artists have created a series of pieces that reflect their time spent getting to know the people involved in the clubs from players to volunteers to fans.Each artist used a iety of disciplines including photography, linocut, screen printing, photogravure and knitting.Cromarty artist John McNaught spent time with Skye Camanachd. He grew up in Skye and utilised his skills in printmaking and photography to produce mixed media prints celebrating the clubrsquos  years.Artist and former Lovat player Tom Smith worked with Beauly shinty club to develop an interactive piece showcasing three stories at a local, national and international level and through the use of augmented reality bring history to le.Highland Print Studio director Alison McMenemy said: ldquoThe whole project has been great and a huge learning experience.ldquoShinty is a unique sport and the level of commitment from the communities to running the clubs is quite remarkable.Wednesday  Feb  : AM

title: Inverness firm says Brexit is making customers cautious
story: UNCERTAINTY over the UKrsquos withdrawal from the European Union is causing people to delay home improvements according to an Inverness company.Cairngorm Windows has enjoyed its best start to a year in  years but managing director David Dowling says domestic customers are holding off finalising orders.ldquoPeople carrying out house improvements are approaching us but Brexit is delaying them from pressing the button he said.ldquoIn addition, our German fitted kitchen supplier have notied us of a . per cent import duty tax on all deliveries after March  in the absence of a deal going through.ldquoHowever, wersquove a record-breaking forward workbook thanks to the strong volume of orders from housebuilders while council contracts are at their highest level in  years.A pound, new computer operated cutting machine was fitted in January to drive forward Cairngormrsquos high-tech production process which saw a record , windows manufactured last year.The company aims to produce , windows this year and break the , barrier next year.Mr Dowling said housebuilders like Tulloch Homes, Springfield Homes, Compass and Scotframe had signicantly stepped up their forward orders while windows were being sold as far away as Swindon.Wersquove a strong domestic business where we supply and fit from fitted windows to fitted kitchens, he said.ldquoBut customers are currently telling us theyrsquore holding off the spend because of Brexit causing uncertainty to household budgets.ldquoWe hope that situation clears before too long.The company, which employs  people, installed a pound, automatic welder and corner cutter last year.It has been in business for  years.Wednesday  Feb  : AM

title: Inverness mentoring project aims to improve lives
story: AN INVERNESS mentoring programme is among the projects set to benefit from a pound million windfall for communities across the Highlands.Communities Secretary Aileen Campbell visited Charleston Academy as she announced the funding under the Scottish Governmentrsquos Aspiring Communities Fund.She met staff and pupils involved with a programme which sees young people mentor younger children at Kinmylies Primary School and Nursery.Charleston is one of nine Highland schools taking part in the Growinggether in the Community scheme run by Forres-based Ecologia Youth Trust which has been awarded pound,.During her visit, Ms Campbell heard from pupils how the scheme is helping to increase their wellbeing and confidence as well as strengthening community links.Jake Weston , who is among those who have taken part, mentored a young boy who was initially isolated from other children.ldquoHe was able to make friends and share lunch at the table with other children which he had not done previously, he said.ldquoI have gained a lot of confidence.Logan Parkersaid she had also grown in confidence.ldquoI would recommend it definitely ndash  per cent, she said.Ms Campbell said local communities understood what worked in their own areas and the funding would enable them to help create a more equal Scotland.ldquoIt will support organisations across the Highlands and Islands to deliver tangible, innovative approaches to improve lives based on local priorities and will address poverty and inequality in their area, she said.Wednesday  Feb  : AM

title: Inverness pupils show winning ways in business competition
story: YOUNG business brains from across the Highlands were put to the test in a competition which sharpened their entrepreneurial skills and raised money for a deserving cause.Teams of six from local schools competed in the event organised by Highland Hospice.Secondary school pupils took each other on for the Young Highland Apprentice title, while primary children battled it out in their own junior event.The aim in both cases was to come up with a new product or service that could be sold to raise funds for the hospice.Pupils from Lochardil Primary School in Inverness triumphed in the junior category for their Rocks and Crosses game, a version of noughts and crosses using hand-painted rocks which comes with a gt bag that doubles up as the game board.Sales raised a total of pound. and saw the school crowned winners after a presentation at Inverness College UHI this week.Judges said they were impressed with their business acumen as well as their knowledge of the hospice and the work it does.Winning pound for their school courtesy of event sponsors Tailormade Moves, teacher Muriel Murray said: ldquoTheyrsquore delighted, really proud of themselves.ldquoItrsquos good to see their hard work recognised.In the older age category it was a team from Fortrose Academy who were triumphant, and Tain Royal Academy were runners-up.A team of fth years ran a whole iety of fundraising events between September and January that allowed them to present the hospice with a cheque for pound..Speaking about the impact of the competition as a whole, hospice community fundraiser Katie Gibb said: ldquoAs Highland Hospice is a vital service for the whole of the Highland community, this is a great way for us to raise awareness about our services within the younger generation.Wednesday  Feb  : AM

title: Last phase of Ness Islands work to take place next week
story: The final phase of improvement works on the Ness Islands is set to resume next week.Highland Councilrsquos city of Inverness area committee approved pound, of common good funding for improvement works on bridges, tree maintenance, pathways and bank erosion works, to take place in stages over  months.This final phase will start on Monday, concentrating on restructuring and repairing paths leading up to some of the bridges to enable smoother access for wheelchairs and prams.As part of this work the Wells Bridge will be closed for around a week.Other routes around the islands will still be accessible.Wednesday  Feb  : AM

title: New Nairn homes help meet demand
story: An affordable housing scheme in Nairn has welcomed its first residents, after Albyn Housing Society took handover of the development.The  new-build homes in Farnack Street have been allocated for affordable rent via the Highland Housing Register, providing much-needed accommodation for local applicants.This included a specially adapted property to support the needs of -year-old Shauni McCallum and her family.The new home is adapted to be wheelchair accessible, and also benefits from the inclusion of a large en-suite wet room with hoist provision and a carport.Her mother Myra Wardhaugh said: ldquoOur new home was specially adapted for Shaunirsquos requirements and we canrsquot even begin to express what a dference it has made.ldquoWe can now enjoy spending time in the home, as a family, without any added stress.Albyn Housing Society worked with contractor Springfield Properties to deliver the project in just  months.The new housing development represents a total investment of almost pound. million, with Scottish Government support totalling more than half that amount.Society chief executive Calum Macaulay said: ldquoWe have ambitious build plans for the coming years as we strive to meet growing demand for affordable homes.In the past year, the society has completed affordable housing developments in Inverness, Kirkhill, Alness and where.Wednesday  Feb  : AM

title: Roads not safe for city cyclists says Inverness campaigner
story: A LOT needs to be done to bring roads in Inverness up to a standard that makes them safe and easy for road users to navigate, a leading cycling campaigner has said.Brian MacKenzie, convener of the Highland Cycle Campaign, said: ldquoI cycle a lot and there is no doubt the roads in the town are in very poor condition.ldquoThe trunk roads, too, need attention.Championing the cause for better and safer routes for cyclists he said drivers also need to be aware of cyclists and give greater consideration to them.ldquoDrivers often criticise cyclists when they see them weaving along certain routes but often they are doing that simply to avoid potholes and are taking evasive action, he said.ldquoAt the Raigmore Interchange, on the ramp joining the A south from the A, there is a pothole which has been there for some time. It is now gathering water and there is a warning sign for traffic alerting them to flooding.ldquoThere are also two more long potholes which are much more dangerous for cyclists and motorists just as you enter the interchange off the northbound ramp, coming from the Beechwood direction of the A.ldquoThe seal between the interchange and the ramp has gone andyou are cycling along there on a dark night you canrsquot see it, so your wheel can get caught up in it. These are like tram lines and they could throw you off a bike and cause serious injury.ldquoEvery vehicle coming from the A has to go across these potholes as they enter the interchange as well and they have been like that for a considerable time.ldquoI am wondering when the trunk roads people are going to carry out these repairs.While Highland Council is responsible for the upkeep of most roads in Inverness and the surrounding towns and villages, Bear Scotland is responsible for trunk roads.A spokesman for the organisation told the Courier last week that major defects, including deeppotholes which could pose a danger to road users, are repaired within  days, with safety inspections of all roads under its care inspected on a weekly basis.Wednesday  Feb  : AM

title: signs good for pauls return
story: Aberdeen#s Paul Lawrie says the “signs are good” ahead of histo Tour action.Lawrie, , will play the Oman Open next week, before the Qatar Masters –starting March  – after recovering from foot surgery.The  Open champion at Carnoustie, Lawrie ended his  season early to finally have a problem taken care of which developed before Europe’s miraculous Ryder Cup victory at Medinah in .“Chippy”, as he is affectionately known because of his watertight short-game, said: “We’ve booked our flights and hotel for Oman and Qatar, so I’m on my way.“I’ve only played two  holes – two full rounds since surgery.“So I thought Oman and Qatar being out there and a little bit warmer would help me see where I am, where my game is and whether I can crack on and play or not.“The signs are good, my foot’s been brilliant. My back’s not been %, but you’d expect that from such a long lay-off.“I’ve not played on the Tour properly since April.”Lawrie, who yesterday announced his new charity Pro-Am event to be held at Gleneagles on July , has spoken often of how a problem which started as an uncontrollable tapping of his left foot when he played developed into the foot collapsing every time he swung the club.However, the now Senior Tour-eligible player, revealed how a chance encounter finally got to the root of the issue.Lawrie said: “I was in Lundin Links’ clubhouse after I’d announced I wasn’t going to play again the rest of the year and Stuart Barton, a physio, was behind me in the queue.“He said: ‘I’m really sorry to hear. I know you’ve had lots of people having a look at it, but I’ve got a practice just up the road, I’d love to have a look.’“He asked me to walk up and down and straight away he said: ‘you’ve got a ruptured tendon and problem with the ligament in your foot, that’s why it’s collapsing when you swing.’“He contacted Gordon Mackay, who’s one of his best mates.“I was in Munich and everywhere trying to get my foot fixed and Stuart noticed it straight away.“I’d never met him before.“But I’ve been rehabbing with him the whole way through. He’s phenomenal at his job, just phenomenal.”Mackay performed Lawrie’s surgery in September and the golfer says the medic is delighted with his progress.He said: “He’s extremely happy.“I think it’s taken a bit longer than he thought to recover.“I probably started hitting balls a bit early.“It was quite a big op he did and a big scar on my foot.“I had a ruptured tendon, torn ligament and some bone spurs on it.“You just assume nowadays itis going to be keyhole or whatever.“You’re looking at  or  weeks, but for me it’s been a bit longer.”Lawrie is now painkiller free while playing for the first time in “six or seven years”.He said his foot felt “really strong” while playing at Montrose in the North-east Alliance last week.In his time off he’s had plenty to smile about, with long-time Paul Lawrie Foundation player David Law winning on the European Tour for the first time – at the ISPS Handa Vic Open in Australia – after only five starts.Lawrie, who thinks Law’s biggest asset is the unteachable ability to win coming down the stretch when he’s got the chance, said: “He came in on Monday with his little girl – and I met him when he was a little boy.“I’m chuffed for him, and you can see from the reaction to his win what a popular guy and nice boy he is.“I’ve not seen a reaction like that for a long time.“He’d be the first to admit it happened quicker than he would’ve thought – he’s only played five events as a full cardholder.“It’s up to him , but he’s obviously going to get a lot of confidence from that.“We had our chat this week.“He’s got to knuckle down pretty quickly and get back on the range, get back on the chipping green.“He’ll have spells coming up where he doesn’t play his best and he’s got to dig in.”Lawrie is also pleased with how another protege, Sam Locke, has adjusted to pro le after winning the Silver Medal for top amateur at Carnoustie last summer, revealing he’s had chats with the -year-old about the importance of getting the ball in the hole above all  at this level.The Farmfoods Paul Lawrie Invitational at Gleneagles will see groups of one Tour pro, one celebrity and two amateurs tee it up for charities, including Lawrie’s foundation, the Doddie Weir Foundation and Beatson.Taking place on the Monday between the Scottish Open at the Renaissance Club and Open at Royal Portrush, Lawrie hopes the event will prove popular.His annual challenge match in the north-east will be unaffected, with Women’s Open winner Catriona Matthew this year’s opponent.Lawrie said: “We also have the Paul Lawrie Challenge Match at the golf centre – that’s still going to go ahead.“I’m playing Catriona Matthew this year, so I better get practising.“That’s on July  at the golf centre.”

title: cairndow author at lochgilphead bookshop
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowOne of Argyll#s most dynamic social entrepreneurs has drawn on her Cairndow upbringing to write a truly fascinating book # and she will shortly be signing copies in Lochgilphead.Christina Noble used notes from her father#s journal and estate records, blending these with the recollections of the people of the estate to create Ardkinglas # the biography of a Highland estate.The book is a tale of the people, places and stories on Ardkinglas Estate since , when Christina#s great grandfather, industrialist Sir Andrew Noble, purchased the ,-acre property.Speaking at the book#s official launch in , she said: #Ardkinglas is a place that is very dear to me, and the place and the people have contributed to making me who I am today. It feels like home.#Christina, though, is never one to dwell too long on the past. In this book she has more than one eye on the future, asking pertinent questions about the potential for land use and communities as Scotland#s looks ahead.Having been one of the driving forces behind the creation of the #Here We Are# community enterprise at Clachan, Cairndow, she practices what she preaches. Now a store for a wealth of local memory and knowledge, Here We Are # situated beside the Tree Shop # hosts a post office and much more besides. It wasn#t long before Here We Are spawned  Our Power, a community energy business selling dried woodchip and with a stake in the Merk Hydro scheme in Glen Fyne. It is all about helping forge a sustainable future for rural communities.Saturday February  offers the chance to meet and have a chat with the author as she visits the Argyll Book Centre in Lochgilphead for a book signing between pm and pm.Refreshments will be available as you come along and have your copy signed.PIC:Christina Noble with a copy of her book. _aChristinaBook

title: dancing brings light and beauty amid the grief to ardfern
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe Nowby Laura MaxwellWithin This Dust is an interpretive dance performance inspired by the most horrying incident of our time: the   terror attacks.A packed Craignish Village Hall held host to the Dundee-based Shaper Caper performance on Wednesday February .Inspired by photographs of the   fallout, choreographer Thomas Small has created a performance that has been seen to bring tears due to its beauty and the tragedy of this story. First performed in , Within This Dust has gone on to be staged all over the UK and internationally, including at the   memorial and museum.Especially inspired by Richard Drew#s unforgettable photograph, The Falling Man, Within This Dust details the experience of witness, Lisa Hood, and victim, Vince Virr, of the   attacks.The witness finds herself surrounded in dust, made of crumpled paper, and begins a grieving process of hunting through the papers, finding meaning in the words, as someone tries to tidy around her. The second act features the victim joining the witness, creating a connection that will inevitably be broken, when finally, in the third act, the victim is alone, caught between a choice of the smoke and fire within the collapsing building or the  metre drop to freedom.It was a very poignant performance, tenderly expressing the horror of the incident, perhaps now weakened due to overindulgence. When the lights came up everyone stayed where they were, perhaps a little too stunned to move. Chatter was in whispers, for respect to people who could not hear them.As the narrator of the show captured and pieced together from coverage of the attacks said, the dust has not settled, and never will. The losses of the people in the planes and buildings is still felt, and the wider western world is still wary, still learning, still recovering.Within This Dust manages to depict the horror of that day beautully, and more importantly, delicately. No easy task for a grieving world.PIC:Craignish Village Hall was full. _aWithinThisDustLisa Hood amongst the #dust#. _aWithinThisDustDancer, Lisa Hood. _aWithinThisDustLisa Hood collecting dust. _aWithinThisDustLisa Hood and Vince Virr. _aWithinThisDustDancer, Vince Virr. _aWithinThisDustVince Virr facing the smoke, or the window. _aWithinThisDust

title: letters week 06
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSirWe would like to take this opportunity to thank all of those who have either given or offered assistance and support to my family following the fire at our home on the night of January , and a special thanks to the emergency services that attended.Anyone who was present either at the time or who has seen the remains will appreciate the level of destruction wrought upon our home and the contents within, however, as noted in this paper last week, all of us were unharmed and have been provided with accommodation nearby.The support given by friends, work and the wider community has been truly humbling, and as a family we thank you all and look forward to ing to our home, hopefully sometime next year.Thank you,Alan and Gillian Pitman, The Old Church, ArdrishaigSir,I must commend our MP Brendan O#Hara on his vision and wisdom on his recent fact-finding trip to the Faroe Islands to see first hand how The Faroese inter-connect their islands with  subsea and through mountain tunnels.This common sense approach guarantees safe connectivity   in any weather providing confident travel which is the least the people of Mid Argyll, Kintyre, Islay and Jura should expect. This area of Argyll is the most fragile in the region. The people of Argyll, businesses and visitors deserve no less.Forget the squandering of £m on unreliable, mitigation measures trying to justy a flawed decision made many years ago to use the Old Military Road as a ersion which has failed on many occasions and now has a landslip between the two roads. Forget the expensive excavation of pits by the A rather use the cuttings into the hillside to form a two lane road protected with a flow over canopy with closed outer edges at the four problems gullies. If the contractors on the present scheme can work without any road closures then the flow over canopy option would not lead to closures as many officials and some politicians claim.This is a red herring postponing #a proper solution#. When this is option is completed it will save on the expense of manning the ersion route involving - personnel and - vehicles, replacing expensive nettings, delays whilst the farmer clears his animals and collect his fees. A scandalous waste of public money. Solve The Rest Landslides and stop wasting on mitigating measures.Like Brendan O#Hara I#m neither an engineer or geologist but both of us are blessed with plain common sense. If the Faroese can build a tunnel at £.m per kilometre surely a simple open sided m canopy would cost considerably less. In  at Dawlish .km of double tracked railway and .km of sturdy seawall was built at a cost of £m in eight weeks. Why have we in Argyll after nine years, four dferent Transport Ministers and £m spent and still have no guaranteed safe passage   on The Rest and Be Thankful Follow the Argyll Advertiser#s campaign #Invest in the Rest#. Transport Minister Michael Matheson, Transport Scotland and our Government must abandon their obsession with mitigation measures and fund a permanent solution. We demand no less.Sir,Calls for assurances that the Rest and Be Thankful section of the A will be improved to resist future landslides were made during a session of Transport, Infrastructure and Connectivity questions in the Scottish Parliament.I quizzed transport secretary Michael Matheson, about what was discussed at the last meeting of the A Taskforce in November , and asked what assurances the Cabinet Secretary could give to local residents and businesses who rely on the A being open at all times.The Rest and Be Thankful was closed off for nine days in October  following the largest landslide in a decade, forcing road users to either take a major ersion, or to use the Old Military Road during certain hours of the day.A number of petitions were created during the period of the incident, including one by myself, calling for a permanent solution to the Rest and Be Thankful.The transport secretary said that the meeting was #full and frank#, and that there would be a #review of the potential for additional landslide mitigation measures at the Rest and Be Thankful#, and that this would be discussed at the next A Taskforce meeting in March .There was also a commitment that Argyll and Bute would be #prioritised# in the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.I welcome the assurances by the transport secretary that there will be a review of any additional measures for the Rest and Be Thankful, and that Argyll and Bute will receive priority at the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.Donald Cameron, MSPReserve forcesSir,Last issue#sletter raising concerns about the UK government’s proposed use of the army’s reserve force in the event of a no-deal Brexit is timely.In case anyone out there still thinks a no-deal Brexit is a good idea it’s worth noting that the legal authorityof Reserve Forces Act  allowing the Secretary of State to take this step requires him to establish that it is necessary #for the alleviation of distress or the preservation of le or property in time of disaster or apprehended disaster#.Enough said.Frances Roberts, Ardrishaig

title: rest and be thankful mitigation project moves to next phase
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowThe next phase of the works to form landslide mitigation catch-pits next to the A at the Rest and Be Thankful is now underway.The £.M project started in spring  with works now continuing with the construction of the fourth catch-pit next to the road side.  These landslide mitigation measures involve the excavation of debris flow catch-pits next to the A.The catch-pits are designed to stop debris reaching the road from a landslide down the channels above each catch-pit location, helping to keep the A open.  Once completed, this fourth catch-pit will provide an additional , tonnes of debris storage capacity, bringing the total volume protection of the catch-pits to approximately , tonnes.In addition to the catch-pits, works on the additional protection measures at Glen Kinglas, approximately three miles from the Rest and Be Thankful, will continue.  The works at Glen Kinglas involve the re-use of the excavated rock from the Rest and be Thankful to form landslip mitigation bunds above streams along Glen Kinglas. The bunds will help reduce the risk of debris reaching the A in the event of a landslide.This project allows BEAR Scotland to maximise the benefit of recycling the material being excavated from the Rest and Be Thankful while minimising the overall cost of these works.To keep roadworkers and motorists safe throughout the works, temporary traffic lights will be in place on the A at each location. This next phase of the works is expected to last approximately  weeks.Commenting on the works, Eddie Ross, BEAR Scotland’s North West Representative said: #The installation of the next stages of the mitigation measures will provide more protection and resilience against any future landslips blocking this key route at both the Rest and Be Thankful and Glen Kinglas.#The temporary traffic lights are necessary to keep our teams as well as users of the route safe during the works, and the teams will do all they can to complete the project as quickly and safely as possible.#We encourage road users to plan their journeys in advance by checking the Traffic Scotland website for up to date travel information.#

title: human rights monitor philppa bonella speaks at ms centre
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowSt Margaret’s Justice and Peace Group invited Philppa Bonella to Lochgilphead on Tuesday February  to talk about her experiences as a human rights monitor on the Ecumenical Accompaniment Programme in Palestine and Israel .She was in the Holy Land for three months last year and spent time on the West Bank in Palestinian villages surrounded by Israeli settlements.Philippa told her audience that the EAPPI sends batches of people of all nationalities to the Holy Land for these three-month stints, where the monitors are split into small groups and must operate in pairs for safety.She recalled particular incidents – schools tear-gassed by Israeli troops, homes searched in raids during the middle of the night, families prevented from picking their olives, Palestinian villages surrounded by Israelis in mobile homes, supported by Israeli government-funded water and electricity supplies.Human rights monitors must be impartial and Philippa did her utmost to present a balanced picture and all EAPPI monitors share their findings and experiences with the UN with the intention of furthering solutions in this troubled region. Her conclusions drawn from experience was that when the monitors were around, there may have been unpleasant situations, but no tragedies. When there was no monitor around – clearly defined by their unorms – people died.Philippa had only been home for eight weeks when she spoke to the Justice and Peace Group, and she admitted that she was still processing the often brutal and violent scenes she had witnessed. And though she wryly joked that it had not exactly been a picnic, she encouraged her audience to become involved in the work of EAPPI – through prayer, support, even by volunteering to be a monitor .For more information, visit eappi.org en or visit the EAPPI Facebook page @EAPPI.WCCPIC:Her stories of the hardships in Israel kept visitors engaged. no_aholylandPhillipa Bonella speaking at the MS Centre. no_aholyland

story: NewsAyr Rugby Club near move to new town centre base at Dam Park as they prepare to sell Millbrae homeThe Millbrae men, who top the Tennents Premiership, are in advanced talks to sell their Millbrae home and move to Dam Park in Ayr town centre.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  OCT NewsDam Park could play host to Ayr Rugby Club as soon as  "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBooming Ayr Rugby Club are nearing a deal to sell their Millbrae home and move to the town centre. Plans to buy council-owned Dam Park are at an advanced stage. The club, currently top of the Tennent’s Premiership, hope the bold switch will take them to the next level. Ayr would earn a multi-million pound jackpot by hiving off their own land for housing, with builder Cala Homes believed to be preferred bidder for the site. And they plan to use part of the cash for a pound, synthetic surface to be laid at their new home. Club chiefs have spent the last year in talks over a move and hope to seal the deal soon.  If the switch is rubber-stamped by South Ayrshire Council Ayr could be playing out of Dam Park as early as . One source said: “It is the move that makes sensethe club is to continue growing. “Next season sees the start of the Super Six set-up with games to be broadcast live on television. “It is potentially a great  for Ayr and bringing the club into the heart of the town can benefit so many.” The switch would see Ayr Seaforth Athletic Club on the move to a new sporting centre planned for Craigie. And junior side Whitletts Victoria couldto the heart of their community with a revamp of the old activity complex on the cards. Ayr rugby supremo Billy McHarg said talks on the move are progressing well.  He said: “Discussions to this point have been positive. “We’re keen to work with all parties to find the right solution and one which will benefit the whole town. “We feel that Ayr Rugby Club coming into the town centre would be a big step forward.” Club members would still have to approve such a move. Ayr have been at scenic Millbrae since . Prior to that they played out of Newton Park, Dam Park, the Old Racecourse and King George V playing fields. Whitletts chairman John Dalton said: “Talks have been very positive and we are currently looking at alternative options. “The football park at Whitletts is the obvious route to go down and would represent ahome to our roots. “A lot of water is still to go under the bridge but as Ayr’s junior football club we are viewing this as a positive opportunity.” Craigie councillor Ian Cavana said: “It may be that a deal is close but nobody will be moving anywhere until the new sports centre at Craigie is up and running. “Work is due to start on that next summer and that’s when we should see real progress.” A council spokesman said: “Discussions on the future of Dam Park are ongoing.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilAyr NewsAyrAyr Rugby

title: ayr united 2 inverness 3
story: NewsAyr United  Inverness : John Roberston hails Somerset Park among best grounds in worldThe Inverness gaffer was full of praise for the old fashioned surroundings as his side clung on in the face of a stirring fightback.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsNathan Austin puts Caley - up "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailJohn Robertson hailed Somerset Park as one of the best grounds in the WORLD after Caley held off a storming Ayr fightback. Inverness were three up and on easy street after a crazy opening  minutes which saw United gt-wrap the game. But a Lawrence Shankland inspired comeback almost grabbed a share of the spoils for Ian McCalls title contenders. A relieved Robertson said: Had it finished - you wouldnt have been surprised. Somerset Park is one of these grounds that sucks you inyou give them a snf. Its a good throwback and their fans make it intimidating and a good atmosphere for teams when you lose a goal. Its brilliant...one of the best grounds in the world to come and play your football. In the past we might have lost a game like this so Im delighted.  Ayr knew a win here would take them top of the Championship and started well with Robbie Crawford missing a good chance in the first minute. But they soon hit the self destruct button as their defence went AWOL to allow Nathan Austin in for a double before Liam Polworth rammed home a third. The game looked over with barely  minutes on the clock and shellshocked Ayr took time to regroup. Coventry-bound Michael Rose rocked the post with a header before Michael Moffat drew a fingertip save from Cammy Mackay. McCall turned to the bench at half time and introduced top gun Shankland who immediately turned the tide. He set up Declan McDaid to haul Ayr back into the contest with a close range finish eight minutes after the restart. And a resurgent Ayr thought they had a penalty when Carl Tremarco appeared to handle in the box but ref Nick Walsh waved away loud protests. United continued to pour forward as the clock ticked down and Shankland set up a grandstand finish when slamming home a  yard free kick with five minutes left.  But their comeback proved too little too late as Inverness clung on. Ayr boss McCall said: Im just gutted. Weve conceded three goals and at least two of them were gted with just crazy defending. And were the team with the best defensive record in the league. I think a draw would’ve been fair but it’s just one of those nights. It’s a dficult one to take to get beat.They’re a big strong team and at times we didn’t cope with that.Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnAyrAyr NewsAyr United FC

title: requested ayr bus stop rejected
story: NewsRequested Ayr bus stop rejected over safety concernsBus firm Stagecoach had followed up on a request to carry out a site visit for a proposed stop at Hollybush Inn after a bus user called for improvement last year.ShareByAbi Smillie:,  FEB NewsThe bus stop request at Hollybush Inn has been rejected "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailRequests to create an official bus stop on a busy  mph road stretch have been knocked back over road safety concerns. Bus firm Stagecoach had followed up on a request to carry out a site visit for a proposed stop at Hollybush Inn after a bus user called for improvement last year. Stranded Suzanne Anderson, , hit out at Stagecoach bosses in December after she was left walking along a dangerous road when a driver failed to stop at Hollybush Inn. Suzanne, of Patna, insisted the stop had always been a ‘traditional unofficial stop’ but the bus firm confirmed this was not the case- nor had it been for ‘many years’. She appealed to Stagecoach to implement an official stop after she left to walk along the busy  mph zone A to the next bus stop. Suzanne previously told the Post: “It’s always been a traditional unofficial stop. “I then had to walk along a dangerous road to another stop to catch a bus.   “They come flying along that road at some speed. Prevention is better than a cure. If that happens to someone  and they had to walk along the road and a lorry comes thundering down- who knows what could happen.” Despite Stagecoach stating Hollybush Inn is not a registered stop, the firm raised the request to install an official one with transport agency SPT. And with checks carried out, the unanimous decision was that the location is unsuitable for an official stop. A Stagecoach West Scotland spokensman said: “Following on from the information provided by the Ayrshire Post on December  in relation to a customer trying to board one of our services at the Hollybush Inn, we can advise that a site visit has been carried out by representatives of SPTand East Ayrshire Council. “It has been agreed that the suggested location is unsuitable for bus stops, due to road safety concerns and the lack of suitable footways. The location of bus stops is decided jointly by representatives of SPT and East Ayrshire Council Roads department with the prime considerations in assessing the suitability of sites being road and pedestrian safety.”

title: weve bin refusemen dump recycling
story: NewsWeve bin had as refusemen dump all recycling together in AyrAmazing footage shows binmen dumping all the recycling together in back of wagonShareByStephen Houston:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.dailyrecord video video-watch-binmen-pour-separated-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBrazen binmen were caught dumping loads of separated recycling into the back of the same refuse lorry. The shocking evidence makes a mockery of the new flagship South Ayrshire Council recycling policy, which has cost a fortune in public cash. The bin team were filmed as they uplted four giant refuse containers and put them all in the same wagon. The pair of hi-vis clad refusemen did not appear to care who was watching as all the waste was dumped into the back of their lorry, driven by a third council staffer. They were recorded on video for four minutes after they arrived at the bin corral in Ayr’s Newmarket Street. The binmen first lted the purple-lidded container for paper, card and cardboard then a green one for general waste, a blue for metal and plastic cartons before a fourth, which looks like another purple bin. It happened at .am on February . Our source said: “What I saw was disgusting. “How can these people look themselves in the eye  “The council has bombarded us with information and leaflets on our new recycling. “What is the point ” The evidence emerged following our report last week on the same thing happening in Girvan. Another resident on the outskirts of Ayr has said their bins had been mixed. Sarah McGhee said: “This practice could be widespread as friends of my husband Andy have reported the same thing. It is so disheartening for everybody who is separating everything and I am so angry. “I would feel happierthe council are now forced to let people into their recycling centre to see what is actually happening.” She watched from her kitchen window at Mainholm Smallholdings in the first week of January as the blue and green bins were emptied into the same load. The council rolled out the new system between October and last week and will continue to stage community roadshows to explain the system until next week. They want to reduce the , tons of household waste sent to landfill every year from , homes. It has not funded all the cost of the new bins and got a grant from Zero Waste Scotland. South Ayrshire Council is claiming their binmen took the action due to the PUBLIC and refused to issue rebuke to staff or apology. They alleged the rubbish had all been contaminated.A spokesman said: “The Council is committed to recycling as much as possible, unfortunately not everyone feels the same.Our recycling facilities in some areas, such as town centres, can be heavily contaminated by householders and the general public putting waste in the wrong bins.We have written to residents in the Newmarket Street area reminding them of their recycling responsibilities and we ask the public to use bins correctly so we don’t have to put contaminated recycling to landfill.”*Help us keep an eye on the recycling rogues. If you see it happening get them on video and let us know on  Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilEnvironmentAyrAyr NewsGirvan

title: st-ronans-honour-the-bard
story: THE pupils of St. Ronanrsquos School in Innerleithen once again honoured the Bard by holding their th Annual Burns Lunch last week.As well as celebrating the birth of Robert Burns, the event commemorated the poets visit to Innerleithen in  when he took tea at Pirn House, where the school now stands.The schoolrsquos lunch was arranged by the Primary  pupils with guests from the community as well as the Primary  pupils and senior pupils from partner school, Walkerburn.In the chair was Sarah Whiteford who kept the proceedings moving along nicely.Piper Jim Hamilton, of Innerleithen Pipe Band, piped in the haggis, and Frances Reilly gave a stirring Address to the Haggis, albeit being a pre-recorded version on the big screen, as Frances was part of the Netball Team battling it out in the Borders School Final.The girls finished runners-up and ed in time for the speeches.Oliver Kennedy said the Selkirk Grace before a team of Primary  waiters and waitresses served up a delicious meal of haggis, neeps and tatties prepared by the St Ronanrsquos kitchen staff.Following the meal, a number of pupils delivered well-researched and humorous speeches.Freya Wilson proposed The Immortal Memory, which was accompanied by an imaginative slideshow.Freya reminded everyone of the Bardrsquos humble beginnings, his visit to Innerleithen and his colourful lestyle.The Toast to the Lassies was proposed by Marcus Adam who recounted Burnsrsquo love of the lassies, while taking the chance to gently poke fun at the girls, ultimately acknowledging that he couldnrsquot live without them.Eve Rathie replied on behalf of the lasses and managed to get a bit of her own back.Other toasts and replies were given by Eilish Henderson , Kylib Crawfordand Josh Landers .The Primary  and  pupils from Walkerburn - Ruby Patterson, Kaden Hunter, Melissa Lucas, Thomas Wilson and Kayleigh Zokas - delivered the reply on behalf of the Guests.St Ronans headteacher Keith Belleville told us: "Each young person taking part was very accomplished in the delivery of their role."The lunch was packed full of entertainment."The choir sang two songs with the children from Primary one getting in on the act with a Scottish version of the Hokey Cokey: The Shooglie Wooglie and a video link to the Nursery saw the children there present a Scottish medley.Throughout the afternoon the winners of the whole school Scots poetry recitation competition had entertained with their verses, which ranged from the works of J.K. Annand to Burns himself and showed off the considerable talent from across the school.The chief guest for the day was Alan Patterson, chairman of St. Ronanrsquos Border Games, who was joined by his we Dawn.Mr Patterson gave an inspiring address before presenting the awards to the winners of the poetry competition.The Burns Lunch closed with the singing of ldquoAuld Lang Syne.

title: more-jobs-and-space-as-specsavers-expand-in-galashiels
story: A LOCAL opticians has began work on a pound, expansion in Galashiels.Work on the major refit at Specsavers Galashiels started this week to provide new facilities, more space and additional services to customers, as well as creating a number of new jobs.The store expansion will see an extra test room added ndash fully kitted out with the latest clinical equipment for eye examination, new call centre capability and a fresh new look.Stuart Forrester, store director of Specsavers Galashiels, said: "Wersquore a big part of the community here in Galashiels and itrsquos so important that our store reflects the fantastic service we offer customers across both optical and audiology."The team is committed to providing our customers with the best possible service and we hope that the investment in our new store will improve their experience and encourage more people to visit us regularly."As well as making up to  more appointments available per week, the revamp will see customers being offered an extended range of Specsaversrsquo own and designer frames to choose from.The store will also continue to offer Digital Precision Eyecare, a cutting-edge way of selecting and fitting customersrsquo glasses, using imaging software on tablet devices.Disruption to customers will be kept to a minimum during the refurbishment.The store will close at pm on Saturday, February and will re-open at am on Monday, February .The grand unveiling of the completed new store is scheduled for March .

title: dementia-increases-in-the-borders-lead-to-redesign-of-services
story: NHS Borders chiefs have recorded regular increases in the number of patients being diagnosed with dementia.But they were among the worst in the country for providing post-diagnostic support services.The most recent figures available show that  Borders were diagnosed with some form of dementia during  .But only were given much-needed support - well down on the Scottish average of  percent.Improvements are on the horizon, though, as changes in the way post-diagnosis services are delivered are being implemented.A spokeswoman for NHS Borders told us: "The Mental Health Older Adults Service is currently working on a redesign of how post diagnostic support is delivered."It is our aim to deliver post diagnostic support that is tailored to the inidual needs of our patients."We have commenced work with a range of stakeholders, testing how we continue to best meet the needs of people with dementia and their families and carers in the Scottish Borders."Figures released by Information Services Division show that there were  new cases of dementia in the Borders during  .And the following year there were .The NHS Borders spokeswoman explained that recent changes make data comparisons for post-diagnostic services dficult.She added: "We have introduced a new IT system which has changed the way that we record and report data and makes reliable comparisons to past performance more dficult."We continue to work with colleagues at Information Services Division to more accurately capture and report on the work that we are doing.

title: borders-book-festivals-new-chapter-a-partnership-made-in-print
story: FROM humble beginnings the Borders Book Festival has grown into one of the top literary events in the country.And the -year-old celebration of everything in print is about to open a brand new chapter by teaming up with the regions favourite weekly newspapers.The Borderand Peeblesshire News have become official media partners of the Borders Book Festival.Not only will we bring you all the latest news of who will be turning the pages at Harmony Gardens this June, but we will have exclusive interviews with all of the authors, politicians, sports stars and entertainers.Jo Robinson, content editor of the Borderand Peeblesshire News, explained: "We are thrilled to be working so closely with the Borders Book Festival."Every year the organisers bring the biggest names in literature, sport, politics and entertainment to the beautul Harmony Gardens in Melrose - and we will have access to interview all of them for our readers to enjoy."We hope to have lots of live streaming from the festival and all of the news in the build up."The very first Borders Book Festival in  was held in the Wynd Theatre in front of an audience of around .Last year, despite storms causing several events to be cancelled, almost , visitors enjoyed the likes of Ian Rankin, Richard Dawkins, Stacey Dooley, Neil Oliver and The Hairy Bikers.This years line-up is currently being finalised but it already promises to be another star-studded, yet eclectic, line-up that will have some appeal for almost everyone.Borders Book Festival Director Alistair Moffat is delighted with the new media partnership.He said: "Local roots are strong roots."When we started this festival  years ago, we knew that the most important people to attract were our neighbours."If they liked it, then so would others who lived further afield."Over that long period, the festival has grown to become the one moment in the year when the world comes to the Borders. Instead of catching a train to see big names in Edinburgh or London, they come to us in June in Melrose."But we will never forget our local roots and that is why a partnership with the Borderand the Peeblesshire News is vital."We are told that we have more Facebook friends in Dubai than in one of the Border towns and we are determined that with the help of the Borderand the Peeblesshire News, we will change that."This years Festival runs from Thursday, June  through to Sunday, June .As well as talks and signings by many of the biggest names in books, television, sport and politics there will also be the hugely-popular childrens book festival, delightful musical performances, fine dining in the orchard and so much more over the four days.Dont miss the Borderand Peeblesshire News for the full programme of events.Festival co-ordinator Paula Ogilvie believes the Festival has something for everyone. She explained: "The festival is proud of its place in Borders le, working alongside many partner organisations and writersrsquo groups to combine our main festival programme with community events and a  for local authors, artists and youth groups to showcase their work.,params: .push"Young people are at the heart of the celebrations, with thousands of families, nursery and schoolchildren joining us each year at our bustling Family Book Festival and educational events, and many talented local young people form the backbone of our team by helping to shape our programme, and by performing, presenting and welcoming our visitors to Harmony Garden and Orchard in Melrose over a packed weekend in June."We are thrilled to forge this exciting new partnership with our friends at the Borderand Peeblesshire News and canrsquot wait to start sharing all our latest festival news."Further details of the Border Book Festival are available at http:www.bordersbookfestival.org and https:www.facebook bordersbookfestival

title: council-has-long-held-ambition-to-improve-lowood-bridge
story: SCOTTISH Borders Council has lsquolong-held ambitionsrsquo to transform Lowood Bridge, it has been claimed.At last Wednesdayrsquos meeting of Galashiels Community Council, members were told local authority bosses want to ease congestion around the -year-old structure.But it wonrsquot happen soon.Martin Joyce, SBCrsquos director of assets and infrastructure told the meeting: ldquoWhen proposing the new Tweedbank development, we had people come out and look at the bridge to ensure it is suitable to cope.ldquoThe conclusion was that the level of traffic the new development will bring, will be insufficient to replace Lowood Bridge.
